captions.text: music intro
music intro
music intro
music intro
I've got 400 grams here of rhubarb from the garden
given it a wash. Just sort of clank it up into chunks like this, four cloves of garlic
then I've got a thumb sized piece of ginger, just slice it up into
little pieces like that
and get that straight in there
I'm gonna go two nice chillies
one very heaped teaspoon of
five spice
and then four tablespoons of soy sauce, you want four
tablespoons of honey as well, that honey is really required to
balance up our lovely rhubarb here which im also gonna chuck in
and then just whack the old lid on
get yourself a roasting tray and some tin foil
I've got pork belly here
a kilo and then about
a pint
of water
and then I'm gonna pour
this lovely paste in, look at that
bang this in the oven
for about an hour and a half
at 180 Celsius, or 350 Fahrenheit
right that's had an hour and a half
mmm
so that's tasting great now
so get some ground nut oil or sunflower oil in a pan
just one little layer of it. If i get
the chunks out like this
and just place them
straight in there
at the same time
i want to put some noodles in, one of these little packs per person, erm
in some salted boiling water
lid on top
and I wanna just brown this lovely pork off.
Over here
I've got some different cresses
and some picked coriander. So just to bring all those lovely shoots together
Ive got some spring onions here that i want to just finely slice.
So I've got plain boiled noodles here
and that little bit of water that's drippng off there now
keep a bit of that because thats will keep it
light and steamed
I wanna get that lovely sauce
put that right in the middle and then just place that
lovely
rich hot
crisp meat on top
and again
contrasts of textures there
and then at this point in the game
you want to get some of your spring onion, from a height and sprinkle it
right, you want to get some of your sheso, some of your coriander from a height
and sprinkle it over the top
some of the creases and moulis and stuff like that, then just serve it
with half
a lime that you just squeeze over the top
and if you want a bit of extra chilli, brilliant.

comments.text:
Awesome recipe Jamie.... My twist was using frozen cranberries (rhubarb not 
in season and couldn't find frozen, so figured another sour fruit would 
work). Plus once I took the sauce out of the oven, I added a table spoon of 
peanut butter to make it a tad creamier. Wonderful flavours. Thanks.

comments.text:
Five-spice powder is a mixture of five spices used primarily in Chinese 
cuisine but also used in other Asian cookery. Or you could make your own 1 
teaspoon ground cinnamon 1 teaspoon ground cloves 1 teaspoon fennel seed, 
toasted and ground 1 teaspoon ground star anise 1 teaspoon szechuan 
peppercorns, toasted and ground
